name: Opioid Affected Youth Initiative
objective:
Objectives include implementing programs and services that address public safety concerns, intervention, prevention, diversion, and treatment services for children, youth, and families directly impacted by opioid abuse. Sites should work in partnership with representatives from law enforcement, education, probation and community supervision, juvenile court, mental health service providers, medical physicians/examiners, prosecutors, community-based organizations that address substance abuse, child welfare agencies, child protective services, first responders, and other community health agencies.

The performance measures associated with this objective are:

PM 1: Number of individuals
served (by population)
PM 1: Percentage of eligible
individuals served by a multidisciplinary team
beneficiary_types: Specialized group (e.g. health professionals, students, veterans)
applicant_types: Local (includes State-designated Indian Tribes, excludes institutions of higher education and hospitals
categories: Law, Justice, and Legal Services - Law Enforcement Support

results.description: In FY 2018, OJJDP awarded cooperative agreements to six sites and one training and technical assistance provider.
OJJDP awarded nearly $7 million to seven sites under the Opioid Affected Youth Initiative to develop data-driven responses to opioid abuse.
